title: Nonparametric Tests: A Statistical Safety Net
contentHtml:
When working with statistical data, it's common to assume normality or a specific distribution. However, what if your data doesn't fit these assumptions? That's where nonparametric tests come in â€“ a set of powerful tools that don't rely on specific distributions.

In this card, we'll explore four essential nonparametric tests: Wilcoxon, Mann-Whitney, Kruskal-Wallis, and permutation tests. These methods are crucial for ML/AI practitioners, as they provide a way to analyze data without making strong assumptions about its underlying structure.

title: Nonparametric Hypothesis Testing
contentHtml:
In traditional hypothesis testing, we assume a specific distribution (e.g., normality) and test statistics are derived from that assumption. However, in many cases, these assumptions may not hold true, leading to incorrect conclusions. Nonparametric tests offer an alternative by focusing on the rank or ordering of data rather than its actual values.

This approach is particularly useful when dealing with non-normal or categorical data, as well as when sample sizes are small. Wilcoxon, Mann-Whitney, Kruskal-Wallis, and permutation tests are all examples of nonparametric methods that can be used to test hypotheses.

title: Nonparametric Tests: Wilcoxon, Mann-Whitney, Kruskal-Wallis
contentHtml:
In traditional hypothesis testing, we often rely on assumptions about the underlying distribution of our data. However, these assumptions might not always hold true, especially when dealing with non-normal or categorical data.

Nonparametric tests offer a powerful alternative by focusing solely on the rankings or orders of the observations, rather than their actual values. This allows us to make inferences about the population without making strong assumptions about its distribution.
